channel.title: C++ returning values that end with (.00)

item.title: C++ returning values that end with (.00)
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

Make sure you include iomanip. Before you print out your values do this:

cout.precision(4); // You can also use this statement within your cout statements. cout << fixed;
Now your output will have fixed floating-point notation.

See: http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/ios/fixed/

Read full topic
item.source: C++ returning values that end with (.00)

item.title: C++ returning values that end with (.00)
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

printf should do this:

#include <stdio.h>

int main(void)
{
	printf("%.2f\n", 10.00D);
	return 0;
}

Read full topic

item.title: C++ returning values that end with (.00)
item.dc:creator: @Xellium Xellium
item.description:
@Xellium wrote:


still returning a value of just 10 and not 10.00

It did however modify all my other values to a precision of 4 so do I need to place the statement [code]std::setprecision(4)[/code] in another line?

still returning a value of just 10 and not 10.00

It did however modify all my other values to a precision of 4 so do I need to place the statement std::setprecision(4) in another line?

item.title: C++ returning values that end with (.00)
item.dc:creator: @Xellium Xellium
item.description:
@Xellium wrote:

So I’m doing this homework assignment and I’m a bit stuck. The code is executable but the teacher is picky and wants the first value to return as (.00). I’ve scanned through my book looking for some type of operator. I was sure that any value */± double would return a double value. It does for the next two but I can’t get my first return to return in decimal places.

[code=cpp]/*
Program Name: Assignment1.cpp
Chapter: Chapter 2 Assignment 1
Programmer: Zach Marshall
Date: 1/15/2016
Description: A program designed to take the input of a radius.
Then with the input of the radius, it will display circumfrence, area, and diameter.
*/

#include
#include
using namespace std;

int main() {
/Start of Data types/

double radius, diameter, circumference, area;

//start constants
const double pi = 3.14159;

/*End of Data types*/

/*Start of Input/Output statements*/
cout << "Enter the radius of the circle (in inches): ";
cin >> radius; //The user inputs how large the radius is

/*Secondary Datatypes used here because you can't declare radius as a variable without first defining it with the input*/
diameter = 2.00 * radius; //Equation for finding the diameter of a circle
circumference = 2 * pi * radius; // Equation for finding the circumference of a circle
area = pi * pow(radius, 2.0); //Equation for finding the area of a circle (uses power function) (radius*radius)

cout << "The Diameter of a circle with a radius of " << radius << " is: " << diameter << " inches." << endl; //output of the diameter
cout << "The Circumference of a circle with a radius of " << radius << " is: " << circumference << " inches." << endl; //output of the circumference
cout << "The Area of a circle with a radius of " << radius << " is: " << area << " inches." << endl; //output of the area
/*End of Input/Output Statements*/
return 0;

}[/code]

The output if the radius is 10 =

[spoiler]
Enter the radius of the circle (in inches): 10.00
The Diameter of a circle with a radius of 10 is: 20 inches.
The Circumference of a circle with a radius of 10 is: 62.8318 inches.
The Area of a circle with a radius of 10 is: 314.159 inches.
Press any key to continue . . .
[/spoiler]

I have tried entering it with the decimal places and without but no change as seen here.

Read full topic
item.source: C++ returning values that end with (.00)
